questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Pseudophakic bullous keratopathy is/are incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pseudophakic bullous keratopathy (PBK) is caused by endothelial cell loss or dysfunction, commonly after complicated cataract surgery, leading to corneal stromal oedema and painful epithelial bullae.

  • The corneal endothelium is responsible for pumping excess fluid out of the cornea to maintain clarity.
  • Surgical trauma or pre-existing conditions like Fuchs endothelial dystrophy predispose to PBK. (Option C)
  • Descemet';s membrane may remain intact in most cases-the problem lies in the endothelial cells, not the membrane itself. (Option A)
  • Preventive strategies include the use of high-quality viscoelastic, minimal intraocular manipulation, and gentle surgical technique. (Option D)

Key Takeaway: Pseudophakic bullous keratopathy is due to endothelial dysfunction, not Descemet's membrane damage.

questions.text: Which type of light is responsible for photophthalmia injury?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Photophthalmia is an acute inflammatory response of the corneal epithelium to excessive exposure to ultraviolet (UV) radiation, particularly in the 290-311 nm range.

  • The UV light causes toxic damage to the corneal epithelium, leading to epithelial desquamation and multiple punctate erosions.
  • Symptoms start after a latent period of 4-5 hours and include burning pain, photophobia, lacrimation, blepharospasm, and foreign body sensation.
  • Common scenarios include welding arc exposure, cinema studio lights, or reflected UV from snow surfaces (snow blindness).
  • The injury is superficial and self-limiting with epithelial regeneration within 24-48 hours.

Explanation of other options:

Infra-red (Option A): Causes thermal burns to deeper tissues, not superficial epithelial injury.

Visible spectrum (Option B): Not known to cause corneal damage.

X-rays (Option D): Can damage ocular tissues at high exposure, but not typically implicated in photophthalmia.

questions.text: What does the presence of the Kayser-Fleischer ring indicate?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Kayser-Fleischer ring is caused by copper deposition at the level of Descemet's membrane and is a hallmark ocular sign of Wilson disease (hepatolenticular degeneration).

  • Seen as a golden-brown or greenish ring at the peripheral cornea (limbus) when viewed on slit-lamp biomicroscopy.
  • The copper accumulates in Descemet's membrane due to impaired biliary copper excretion.
  • The ring may appear dark or black under cobalt blue light.
  • With systemic chelation therapy (e.g., penicillamine), the Kayser-Fleischer ring may fade or disappear over time.

Explanation of other options:

Iron deposition in Bowman's membrane (Option A): Seen in Fleischer rings of keratoconus, not Wilson disease.

Iron deposition in Descemet's membrane (Option B): Incorrect metal and layer for Kayser-Fleischer ring.

Copper deposition in Bowman's membrane(Option C): Wrong location, Kayser-Fleischer involves Descemet's layer.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not associated with the development of corneal verticillata (vortex keratopathy) ?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Aspirin is not known to cause vortex keratopathy; it does not affect corneal epithelial cell metabolism.

  • Cornea verticillata (also known as vortex keratopathy) is characterised by fine, whorl-like golden-brown opacities in the inferior corneal epithelium.
  • The whorled pattern reflects the centripetal migration of epithelial cells and typically spares the limbus.
  • Common drug-related causes include:
    • Amiodarone: Seen in almost all long-term users. (Option A)
    • Chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine: Dose-independent corneal deposits. (Option B)
    • Indomethacin: NSAID known to occasionally cause vortex patterns. (Option D)
  • Other causes include Fabry disease (a systemic lysosomal storage disorder).

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is/are not associated with corneal opacity at birth?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Megalocornea presents at birth with an enlarged but clear cornea and does not cause opacity.

  • Congenital corneal opacities may arise from various developmental anomalies and are typically present at birth.
  • Common causes of congenital corneal opacity include:
    • Peters anomaly -central stromal opacity with irido-lenticular adhesions (Option A)
    • CHED (Congenital Hereditary Endothelial Dystrophy)- bilateral, diffuse corneal haze from birth (Option B)
    • Sclerocornea- peripheral or total corneal opacification with loss of limbal distinction (Option C)
  • Megalocornea, in contrast, is characterized by non-progressive bilateral enlargement of the corneal diameter (≥13 mm), with the cornea remaining clear.

Mnemonic: STUMPED

  • Sclerocornea
  • Trauma (birth-related)
  • Ulcer
  • Mucopolysaccharidosis
  • Peters anomaly
  • Endothelial dystrophy (CHED)
  • Dermoid

questions.text: Which drug is implicated in the development of Argyrosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Argyrosis is a condition caused by prolonged use of silver nitrate, leading to permanent silver deposition in ocular tissues.

  • Chronic exposure to silver nitrate results in deposition of metallic silver in elastic fibres of the conjunctiva, sclera, and Descemet's membrane of the cornea.
  • The pigmentation appears as a gray-black or slate-colored discoloration, which is typically permanent.
  • Although not vision-threatening, the cosmetic appearance may be distressing to patients.
  • The silver becomes reduced by light exposure and gets deposited in tissues.

Explanation of other options:

Amiodarone (Option A): Causes vortex keratopathy and anterior subcapsular lens deposits, not implicated in argyrosis.

Indomethacin (Option C): NSAID that may cause vortex keratopathy with long-term use, not associated with silver deposition.

Chloroquine (Option D): Causes corneal verticillata and retinal toxicity, not linked to argyrosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is/are indications for performing keratoplasty?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Keratoplasty is indicated in both optical and therapeutic scenarios, including structural damage or visual impairment due to corneal pathology.

  • Perforated corneal ulcer (Option A): An emergency indication for tectonic or therapeutic keratoplasty to restore ocular integrity.
  • Anterior staphyloma (Option B): A late sequela of corneal perforation or infection, keratoplasty may be performed for structural reconstruction or cosmesis.
  • Corneal scar (Option C): If visually significant, especially central, a penetrating keratoplasty (PK) is done for visual rehabilitation.
  • Other common indications include:
    • Bullous keratopathy
    • Keratoconus with failed conservative measures
    • Failed grafts or endothelial dystrophies

questions.text: What is the allowed time frame for harvesting corneas from cadaveric donors?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Corneas for transplantation are ideally harvested within 6-8 hours of donor death to ensure optimal tissue viability.

  • Corneal endothelium is extremely sensitive to hypoxic damage and metabolic derangement after death.
  • In warmer climates (like India), the ideal harvesting window is within 6-8 hours post-mortem.
  • In cold-climate countries or if the body is promptly refrigerated, the window may extend up to 12 hours

Related Important Points:

  • After death, eyes should be closed, and the head elevated to reduce eyelid oedema and corneal clouding.
  • Cooling the body slows down endothelial cell degradation, prolonging the harvesting window.
  • Storage media like McCarey-Kaufman (MK) medium or Cornisol allow preservation for 72 hours or more post-harvest.

questions.text: Which of the following media is used for the preservation of the cornea if the keratoplasty procedure is to be performed within 24 hours?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

For short-term corneal preservation (≤24-48 hours), both McCarey-Kaufman (MK) medium and moist chamber storage are valid options.

  • McCarey-Kaufman (MK) medium: A nutrient-rich, cold-storage medium used for up to 48-72 hours, ideally within 24 hours for best endothelial viability. (Option A)
  • Moist chamber storage: Involves storing the whole eye in a sterile, humidified chamber at 4°C; preferred only if MK medium is unavailable. Also suited for use within 24 hours. (Option C)
  • Eagle's medium is used in organ culture preservation at 37°C, suitable for intermediate to long-term (Option B ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following clinical conditions can be treated using cornea stored in liquid nitrogen?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cryopreserved corneal tissue stored in liquid nitrogen is not optically clear and is therefore used only for tectonic or therapeutic grafts, not for visual rehabilitation.

  • Cryopreservation destroys the transparency of the corneal stroma, making such tissue unsuitable for optical keratoplasty (e.g., keratoconus). (Option A ruled out)
  • It remains structurally useful and is employed to:
    • Maintain globe integrity in perforated corneal ulcers and corneal fistulae.(Option B)
    • Repair anterior staphylomas and descemetoceles. (Option C)
    • Perform therapeutic grafting in cases of sloughing, infected, or necrotic corneas.

Related Important Points:

  • Optical keratoplasty (e.g., for keratoconus or corneal scarring) requires a transparent cornea with viable endothelium, so cryopreserved tissue is not suitable.
  • Tectonic keratoplasty aims to maintain the structural integrity of the globe and does not require transparency, making cryopreserved tissue suitable.
  • Therapeutic keratoplasty removes infected or melting corneas and uses tissue with antimicrobial support and tensile strength, also allowing cryopreserved use.

choices.text: Absence of epithelial cells in donor tissue
Corneal immune privilege due to avascularity
High mitotic index of corneal endothelium

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient underwent corneal transplantation without prior HLA matching or systemic immunosuppressants. Which of the following best explains the lower risk of graft rejection in this case?
questions.solution:
Explanation:


 The cornea is an immunologically privileged site due to its avascularity, absence of lymphatic drainage, and the presence of local immunosuppressive factors, which reduce the chance of graft rejection.

  • These features prevent antigen presentation to host immune cells and limit inflammatory response.
  • Therefore, corneal transplants typically do not require HLA matching or intensive immunosuppression.
  • This makes corneal grafting the most successful form of solid tissue transplantation.

Related Important Points:

  • Immune privilege is further reinforced by anterior chamber-associated immune deviation (ACAID).
  • Vascularized corneas lose this privilege and are more prone to graft failure.
  • Common indications for corneal transplant include keratoconus, bullous keratopathy, and corneal scars.

Explanation of other options:

Absence of epithelial cells (Option A): Donor epithelium is present at the time of grafting and replaced by host epithelium soon after, this does not confer immune protection.

Use of cryopreserved donor cornea (Option B): Preservation method affects tissue viability, not immune rejection risk.

High mitotic index of corneal endothelium (Option D): The corneal endothelium is non-mitotic; its cells do not regenerate, this option is factually incorrect.

questions.text: Identify the type of keratoplasty procedure highlighted (A) in the picture below.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The diagram demonstrates a partial-thickness corneal graft implanted within the host corneal stroma, consistent with an inlay lamellar keratoplasty.

  • Inlay lamellar keratoplasty involves creating a lamellar pocket or bed in the host cornea and placing a lamellar donor graft within it.
  • This technique preserves the recipient endothelium and Descemet's membrane.
  • It is typically indicated for anterior stromal pathologies like corneal scars not involving deep layers.

Related Important Points and Concepts:

  • Inlay Lamellar Graft: Positioned within the host corneal stroma.
  • Onlay Lamellar Graft: Lies on the surface of the cornea. (Option C ruled out)
  • Penetrating Keratoplasty: Full-thickness graft. (Option B ruled out)
  • Keratomileusis: Reshaping of the cornea using excimer laser or lenticule (e.g., LASIK/SMILE). (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following is/are not complications noted in the early post-operative period of keratoplasty?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Astigmatism and recurrence of primary disease are late or very late complications of keratoplasty, not seen in the early postoperative period.

  • Early postoperative complications (within 3 weeks) include:
    • Wound leak (Option A ruled out)
    • Shallow anterior chamber
    • Persistent epithelial defect
    • Secondary glaucoma
    • Graft edema
    • Uveitis
    • Graft infection
    • Sterile suture infiltrates
    • Primary graft failure
  • Late complications (after 3 weeks):
    • Graft rejection
    • Secondary glaucoma
    • Suture-related issues
    • High astigmatism (Option B)
  • Very late complications (after 1 year):
    • Graft rejection
    • Recurrence of primary disease (e.g., dystrophies, keratoconus) (Option C)
    • Wound dehiscence due to trauma

Related Important Points:

questions.text: Which of the following is /are likely causes of graft failure?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Graft failure can result from multiple mechanisms, including poor donor endothelium, graft rejection, and graft infection-all of which impair corneal clarity and function.

  • Primary graft failure refers to poor or non-functioning donor endothelium from the outset. (Option A)
  • Graft rejection may involve any corneal layer (epithelial, stromal, endothelial), often triggered by immune sensitization. (Option B)
  • Graft infection compromises graft clarity and may lead to necrosis and perforation. (Option C)

Related Important Points:

  • Risk factors for graft rejection:
    • Host stromal vascularization
    • Previous grafts
    • Large/central grafts
    • Herpetic infections
    • Gender incompatibility (male donor to female recipient)
  • Rejection types:
    • Epithelial rejection: Line of abnormal epithelium
    • Stromal rejection: Deep haze, Krachmer spots
    • Endothelial rejection: Khodadoust line, stromal edema
  • Symptoms: Blurred vision, redness, photophobia, and pain, though some cases are asymptomatic.

questions.text: Which of the following is the procedure of choice for Fuchs' dystrophy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Fuchs' dystrophy primarily affects the endothelium, making Descemet Stripping Endothelial Keratoplasty (DSEK/DSAEK) the preferred procedure.

  • DSEK selectively replaces the diseased Descemet's membrane and endothelium, preserving the overlying stroma and epithelium.
  • It offers faster recovery, reduced risk of rejection, and better visual outcomes than full-thickness keratoplasty.
  • DSEK/DSAEK or DMEK (Descemet Membrane Endothelial Keratoplasty) are preferred for Fuchs' endothelial decompensation.

Related Important Points:

  • Customized component replacement is the modern principle:
    • Stromal pathology: Anterior lamellar keratoplasty (e.g., DALK in keratoconus)
    • Endothelial pathology: Endothelial keratoplasty (e.g., DSEK/DMEK in Fuchs')
  • Fuchs dystrophy may progress to bullous keratopathy with decreased visual acuity, glare, and corneal edema.

Explanation of other options:

Deep Anterior Lamellar Keratoplasty (Option A): Ideal for stromal disorders like keratoconus; not useful in endothelial dystrophies.

LASIK (Option B): A refractive surgery technique, not used in dystrophies or corneal decompensation.

Penetrating Keratoplasty (Option D): Full-thickness graft, now reserved for cases unsuitable for lamellar techniques due to higher rejection rates and slower recovery.

questions.text: What is the ideal size difference for donor v/s host corneas in keratoconus?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In keratoconus, the ideal donor cornea is oversized by 0.5 mm to ensure optimal wound apposition and healing.

  • The cone in keratoconus is typically central or paracentral, and proper sizing helps prevent post-op ectasia and astigmatism.
  • An 5 mm donor for an 8 mm host bed allows slightly more tissue overlap, reducing wound leak and providing structural integrity.
  • Oversizing also minimizes the risk of post-operative flattening or distortion of the graft-host junction.

Related Important Points:

  • Donor-host sizing guide:
    • Keratoconus: +0.25 to +0.5 mm donor oversize preferred
    • Aphakia / pediatric grafts: +1.0 mm oversize commonly used
    • Large scars/adherent leucoma: Requires custom sizing
  • Trephine selection is based on opacity location and cone diameter.

Explanation of other options:

8 mm / 8 mm (Option A): Equal sizing can increase tension and risk wound gaping-suboptimal in keratoconus.

8 mm / 8.25 mm (Option B): Acceptable in some cases but may not give ideal tectonic stability compared to 8.5 mm.

8 mm / 9 mm (Option D): Excess oversizing may cause buckling and interface mismatch in keratoconus.

questions.text: Which of the following is /are associated with oversized corneal donor button?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

An oversized donor button provides multiple post-operative benefits including anatomical fit, anterior chamber depth maintenance, and refractive stability.

  • Better wound apposition is achieved when the donor tissue slightly overlaps the host bed, improving healing. (Option A)
  • Oversizing helps maintain a deeper anterior chamber, which reduces the risk of peripheral anterior synechiae and post-keratoplasty glaucoma. (Option B)
  • A mild myopic shift is common with oversized grafts due to the increased central curvature from the larger donor. (Option C)

Related Important Points:

  • Ideal oversizing in keratoplasty:
    • Keratoconus: +0.25 to +0.5 mm
    • Aphakia/children: up to +1.0 mm
  • Proper sizing balances anatomical alignment and refractive outcomes.

questions.text: A 17-year-old patient diagnosed with keratoconus underwent penetrating keratoplasty and was doing well post-operatively. The patient reported symptoms of sudden blurring of vision, eye redness and pain in the emergency department 2 weeks after the procedure. Clinical imaging is as depicted below.What is further line of management in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Acute graft rejection is the most likely diagnosis, and timely steroid therapy is essential to prevent irreversible graft failure.

  • Graft rejection may occur days to years after keratoplasty and commonly presents with pain, photophobia, redness, and sudden vision loss.
  • Hallmark signs include:
    • Khodadoust line (endothelial rejection line)
    • Keratic precipitates
    • Stromal edema or subepithelial infiltrates
  • Management:
    • Hourly topical steroids (e.g., prednisolone acetate 1%)
    • Systemic corticosteroids are necessary for endothelial and stromal rejection.
    • Severe rejection episodes: IV methylprednisolone 500 mg (single pulse)
    • Milder episodes: oral prednisolone

Explanation of other options:

Observation (Option A): Contraindicated; delaying steroids increases the risk of graft failure.

IV antibiotics (Option C): Reserved for infectious keratitis; no signs of infection here.

Re-surgery (Option D): Considered only after failed medical therapy or irreversible graft failure; not first-line.

questions.text: Which of the following patient scenarios is/are not suitable for keratoprosthesis implantation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Keratoprosthesis is a last-resort intervention for bilateral corneal blindness in patients not amenable to traditional keratoplasty due to severe ocular surface disorders. It is not the first-line treatment in any of the above scenarios.

  • Chemical burns in one eye (Option A): Unilateral cases are not indications; keratoprosthesis is reserved for bilaterally blind
  • Advanced Keratoconus (Option B): Best managed with corneal transplantation (DALK or PK), not prosthesis.
  • Fungal corneal ulcer with endophthalmitis (Option C): Requires antifungal therapy and possibly vitrectomy, not keratoprosthesis, especially in active infection.

questions.text: Which of the following elements is not useful for keratoprosthesis fixation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

PMMA (polymethyl methacrylate) is used to construct the optical cylinder; not as a fixation element in keratoprosthesis.

  • The optical component of the keratoprosthesis is a transparent PMMA cylinder. (Option D ruled out)
  • The fixation or support element varies depending on the type of keratoprosthesis and includes biologic materials like bone (in osteo-odonto-keratoprosthesis), cartilage (chondro-keratoprosthesis), and nail (onycho-keratoprosthesis).
  • These support materials allow integration with host tissue and maintain device stability.

choices.text: Cardiac arrest as a cause of death

questions.text: Which of the following is not a contraindication for eye donation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cardiac arrest is a common mode of death in donors and is not a contraindication to eye donation.

  • Eye banks accept corneal donations following cardiac death, provided other criteria are met and no contraindications exist.
  • Contraindications include:
    • Active septicemia or viraemia (Option A)
    • Disseminated hematologic malignancies (Option B)
    • Death from rabies or neurological disease of unknown etiology
    • Unknown cause of death (Option C)
  • These pose risks of transmissible infections or unidentified systemic diseases.

Related Important Points:

  • Corneal tissues are ideally harvested within 6-8 hours post-mortem.
  • Legal next-of-kin consent is required for all donations.
  • Donor evaluation involves medical/social history, physical examination, and serological screening.

questions.text: Which of the following is an accepted method of cornea harvesting from a donor?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Corneal harvesting can be done either by enucleation of the whole globe or by in situ excision of the corneoscleral rim; both are accepted techniques used by eye banks.

  • Enucleation involves removal of the entire eyeball, which is stored in a sterile moist chamber and later processed under aseptic conditions to retrieve the corneoscleral rim. (Option A)
  • Corneoscleral rim excision (in situ) is done directly at the donor site; the rim is dissected and immediately placed into corneal preservation media for transport. (Option C)
  • Both methods are used routinely based on the available setup and expertise.

Related Important Points:

  • Proper storage and transport include:
    • Using thermocol boxes with ice packs to maintain temperature.
    • Processing under laminar flow hoods to avoid contamination.
  • Evisceration is not preferred for eye donation due to risk of contamination and structural compromise of the globe. (Option B ruled out)

choices.text: Thinning of the cornea in the centre
Distortion of the corneal reflex at the centre

questions.text: All of the following findings are typically associated with the condition shown below except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Keratoconus is a bilateral ectatic disorder that most commonly presents during adolescence or early adulthood; not in middle age.

  • The image demonstrates Munson sign, a classic clinical feature of advanced keratoconus.
  • It typically presents with progressive myopic astigmatism, requiring frequent changes in spectacle prescription (Option A)
  • There is progressive thinning of the cornea, most commonly just inferior to the central axis (Option B)
  • Corneal reflex distortion due to conical protrusion is a hallmark of disease progression (Option C )
  • Keratoconus typically presents in teens to twenties, not in middle-aged males. (Option D ruled out )

Related Important Points:

  • Munson sign: V-shaped protrusion of the lower lid on downgaze-seen in advanced keratoconus.
  • Age of onset: Commonly between 10-25 years, with slow progression over years.
  • Visual disturbances: Irregular myopic astigmatism, poor spectacle correction, and glare.
  • Other signs: Oil droplet reflex, Fleischer ring, Vogt';s striae.

questions.text: The optical instrument used for evaluation of
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows a Placido disc, which is used to evaluate corneal topography by reflecting concentric rings off the corneal surface.

  • The Placido disc is a hand-held instrument with alternating black and white concentric rings.
  • It helps evaluate irregularities or steepening on the anterior corneal surface by assessing reflected ring distortion.
  • The reflected image helps analyze the shape, symmetry, and uniformity of the cornea, making it valuable in screening for keratoconus, planning for refractive surgery, and monitoring post-keratoplasty changes.
